bibl.author: Perry, James
bibl.title: Mimosa: or, The sensitive plant; A poem. Dedicated to Mr. Banks, and addressed to Kitt Frederick, Dutchess of Queensberry, Elect.
bibl.note: This publication is a poem about the Mimosa plant, discovered on Otaheite. In the dedication to this poem, author James Perry speaks to Mr. Banks, imploring him to spread the word about this plant and its many significant properties.

bibl.author: Various
bibl.title: The fugitive miscellany. Being a collection of such fugitive pieces, in prose and verse, as are not in any other collection. With many pieces never before published.
bibl.note: At the end of this compilation, a list of "Lately Published" is featured. One of these is listed as "An Epistle from OBEREA, Queen of Otaheite, to Joseph Banks, Esq" which is translated by T.Q.Z. Esq. who was, at the time, professor of the Otehiete language in Dublin.

bibl.author: Fitzgerald, Gerald.
bibl.title: The injured islanders, or the influence of art upon the happiness of nature: a poetical epistle from Oberea of Otaheite to Captain Wallis. By the ...
bibl.note: The author of this poem takes on the persona of Oberea of Otaheite in address to Captain Wallis, speaking of how her way of living has been completely transformed by her being in contact with Wallis and Cook.

bibl.title: Omiah's farewell; inscribed to the ladies of London.
bibl.publisher: printed for G. Kearsly, in Fleet-Street, MDCCLXXVI.
bibl.note: This is a poem in epistolary form from the native Omiah to the ladies of London. The preface details the purpose and context of this poem: Omiah is to return home to Otaheite.

bibl.author: Alexander, William
bibl.title: The history of women, from the earliest antiquity, to the present time; giving some account of almost every interesting particular concerning ...
bibl.publisher: London : printed for W. Strahan, and T. Cadell, in the Strand, MDCCLXXIX
bibl.note: This publication goes into detail about many different cultural aspects of Tahitian women.
